head.title: National Zoo Getting New Chinese Pandas

hedline.hl1: National Zoo Getting New Chinese Pandas

abstract.p: Chinese government approves sending pair of pandas to National Zoo in Washington as part of program to breed endangered animals in captivity; Smithsonian Institution, which runs zoo, will in exchange donate $1 million per year for 10 years to China for panda research and conservation (S)

block.p: The Chinese government said today that it had approved sending a pair of pandas to the National Zoo in Washington as part of a program to breed the endangered animals in captivity.

To get the pandas, the Smithsonian Institution, which runs the zoo, will donate $1 million a year for 10 years to the Chinese for panda research and conservation. The Chinese have similar arrangements with zoos in Atlanta and San Diego.
The Chinese government said today that it had approved sending a pair of pandas to the National Zoo in Washington as part of a program to breed the endangered animals in captivity.

To get the pandas, the Smithsonian Institution, which runs the zoo, will donate $1 million a year for 10 years to the Chinese for panda research and conservation. The Chinese have similar arrangements with zoos in Atlanta and San Diego.
The National Zoo has been without a panda since the Nov. 28 death of Hsing-Hsing, who was given a lethal injection because of irreversible kidney disease. His mate, Ling-Ling, died in 1992.
The pair produced five offspring but none lived more than five days.

Ling-Ling and Hsing-Hsing came to Washington when the Nixon administration was reopening relations with China. The announcement about another pair comes during a debate over trade between the United States and China.

When word of the negotiations surfaced last month, Lawrence Small, secretary of the Smithsonian, said the institution had raised $5.8 million toward the fee set by the Chinese, which then was $8 million.
David J. Umansky, a spokesman for the Smithsonian, said talks were under way with prospective donors.

Among those who have pledged to make donations are the family of J. Williard Marriott Jr., of the Marriott hotel chain, which promised $1.6 million; Ruth Holmberg, who is on the Smithsonian's national board and is a member of the Sulzberger family, which controls The New York Times Company, $1 million; and the AES Corporation and the Chubb Corporation, $800,000 each.
